content.description:
Starts at a vertical crease on Alcatraz wall between "Hoosgal" (arete) and large tree.  Look for a belay anchor at ground level. If desired, you can place a medium cam in the crease before you reach the first bolt. Follow the bolts to the chains. 

  To get there, continue down the creek past the point where it makes a 90 degree left turn below the Cell Blocks. Continue downhill past several bolted routes on the left (40 to Life, Mr. Meanor, & Mug Shot). At the bottom of the hill look up and left to see the Alcatraz Wall.
content.protection: 7 bolts, chains, belayer anchor at bottom

content.description:
This climb heads up the obvious zig-zagging crack on the Alcatraz Wall. This is the last major crag on the east side of the creek as you head down through Jailhouse Rock. To get there, continue down the creek past the point where it makes a 90 degree left turn below the Cell Blocks. Continue downhill past several bolted routes on the left (40 to Life, Mr. Meanor, & Mug Shot). At the bottom of the hill look up and left to see the Alcatraz Wall. 

    This is a nice lead if you're looking for a relaxed climb where you can practice super-easy gear placement.  The 5.7 rating is a bit too stiff.  The hardest move seems to be getting off the ground, after which the route follows the major crack up and right, cuts across the face where the going gets easy, and rejoins the crack up top.
content.protection:
Small and medium cams and stoppers. There are chains up top.

 Bolts and top-anchors updated by CASA in 2017.

content.description:
Machinegun is the right-most climb on Alcatraz Wall.  This is the last major crag on the east side of the creek as you head down through Jailhouse Rock. To get there, continue down the creek past the point where it makes a 90 degree left turn below the Cell Blocks. Continue downhill past several bolted routes on the left (40 to Life, Mr. Meanor, & Mug Shot). At the bottom of the hill look up and left to see the Alcatraz Wall. 

  This route is a very short face climb which is not that interesting.  Climbaz.com recommends carrying extra gear, but this is pretty unnecessary.
content.protection:
Two bolts, plus chains.

 Bolts and top-anchors updated by CASA in 2017.

content.description: This climb heads up cracks on the far left side of the Alcatraz Wall.  This is the last major crag on the east side of the creek as you head down through Jailhouse Rock.  To get there, continue down the creek past the point where it makes a 90 degree left turn below the Cell Blocks.  Continue downhill past several bolted routes on the left (40 to Life, Mr. Meanor, & Mug Shot).  At the bottom of the hill look up and left to see the Alcatraz Wall.  Hoosgal is an easy gear lead up a fractured buttress.  Gear placement isn't always as easy as the climbing, but this is a good beginner route.
content.protection: Bring along small to medium cams and stoppers.  Chains up top.

content.description: Climb face to a ledge where a crack system leads to anchors. ISecond half of route can be safely protected with a light rack. A good one to send a new trad leader up as you can have them clip all the bolt so if the gear is terrible you know they will still be safe.
content.protection: Bolts although the second half can be safely protected with gear.

content.description:
This climb follows the bolts on the face just right of the zig-zagging crack on the Alcatraz Wall. This is the last major crag on the east side of the creek as you head down through Jailhouse Rock. To get there, continue down the creek past the point where it makes a 90 degree left turn below the Cell Blocks. Continue downhill past several bolted routes on the left (40 to Life, Mr. Meanor, & Mug Shot). At the bottom of the hill look up and left to see the Alcatraz Wall. 

    This face climb is probably the best route on Alcatraz Wall.
content.protection:
Three bolts, bring a few small/medium stoppers or cams to get you from the 2nd to 3rd bolt. There are chains up top.

 Bolts and top-anchors updated by CASA in 2017.

content.description: The Alcatraz Wall's ample serving of sun enables moderate sport and gear leaders to warmly climb during the winter months.  Routes get shorter as one moves right up the hill.  The rock is reminiscent of lower mountain crags such as the Ruins.
